subject: Re: [junit] Will JUnit 'fail()' trip up ALL code coverage tools?
msgSnippet: Pat, This is actually an interesting advantage of JUnit 4 s exception-expecting syntax: @Test(expected=Exception.class) @Test public void work() { doWork(); }
messageBody:
Pat,

This is actually an interesting advantage of JUnit 4's
exception-expecting syntax:

@Test(expected=Exception.class)
@Test public void work() {
doWork();
}

No uncovered lines there.

In general, though, I would think that calls to fail could be safely
ignored. For example, another idiom I'll use is

for (String s : strings)
if (shouldntBeHere(s))
fail(s + " shouldn't be here!");

Again, if my tests are running, I'd expect fail not to be executed.

David Saff

pmcb552000 wrote:

> Hi,
>
> Simple question - when using the JUnit 'fail()' method to fail a test
> when I expect an exception to be thrown (as per the JUnit
> documentation), surely *ALL* code coverage tools will report that the
> 'fail()' statement is never executed (since my test correctly throws
> the expected exception):
>
> try {
> doWork();
> fail("Exception should be thrown - GET CODE COVERAGE WARNING!");
> }
> catch (Exception e) {
> // Success!!
> }
>
> Should I try and rework this code, or can I configure Clover (the tool
> I'm currently using that causes me this problem) to tell it to ignore
> JUnit 'fail()' calls?
>
> Thanks,
>
> Pat.
